text:
JONESBORO \- The federal government approved Craighead County residents and
businesses to use a program to receive low-interest loans for disaster relief.

County Judge Marvin Day said Friday that he received word from the Small
Business Administration that it had approved businesses and residents to apply
for the loans.

"So that is really big news so people who have uninsured losses  things like
inventory  they're able to get their business back going, and it'll be
affordable for them because, generally speaking, the interest rates are about
half of what the market rate is," Day said.

Previously, the Small Business Administration approved non-profits that were
involved with efforts to help people after the tornado for the same types of
loans.

Day said the Jonesboro Regional Chamber of Commerce was instrumental in
pushing for county businesses to get the loans.

"We're all real excited that that happened today," Day said on Friday.

According to a press release, the Small Business Administration approves
"long-term disaster loans to businesses of all sizes, private, non-profit
organizations, homeowners and renters to repair or replace
uninsured/underinsured disaster damaged property."

The loans are primarily for people who had their business, non-profit or home
damaged by the March tornado in Jonesboro.

But according to the release, the administration also offers Economic Injury
Disaster loans for businesses that didn't sustain physical damage but have
difficulty conducting business because of the twister.

Northeast Arkansas residents in Craighead, Greene, Jackson, Lawrence,
Mississippi and Poinsett and the Missouri county of Dunklin can apply.

The deadline to turn in applications for the loans is July 20 to receive loans
for physical damage to properties. The deadline for businesses that have faced
economic difficulties because of the tornado is Feb. 22, 2021.

Administration officials recommend that people first file to receive their
insurance money to help with damages that occurred during the tornado.

Administrators have also set up a Virtual Disaster Loan Outreach Center.
Representatives are available by phone at 916-735-1500 or by email at
[FOCWAssistance@sba.gov](mailto:FOCWAssistance@sba.gov) from 6 a.m. to 2:30
p.m. Monday through Friday, according to the release.

People can apply for the loans online at
<https://disasterloanassistance.sba.gov>.

Day made the announcement at the Craighead County Quorum Court on Monday. The
court met, with some justices of the peace continuing to utilize the
opportunity to attend virtually, at 5:30 p.m. in the basement of the
Courthouse Annex, as it has done since Gov. Asa Hutchinson approved for
justices to begin meeting via Zoom. While most justices met in person, a few
continue to meet online to protect themselves from the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Feds OK low-interest loan program
html:
JONESBORO - The federal government approved Craighead County residents and businesses to use a program to receive low-interest loans for disaster relief.

County Judge Marvin Day said Friday that he received word from the Small Business Administration that it had approved businesses and residents to apply for the loans.

"So that is really big news so people who have uninsured losses – things like inventory – they're able to get their business back going, and it'll be affordable for them because, generally speaking, the interest rates are about half of what the market rate is," Day said.

Previously, the Small Business Administration approved non-profits that were involved with efforts to help people after the tornado for the same types of loans.

Day said the Jonesboro Regional Chamber of Commerce was instrumental in pushing for county businesses to get the loans.

"We're all real excited that that happened today," Day said on Friday.

According to a press release, the Small Business Administration approves "long-term disaster loans to businesses of all sizes, private, non-profit organizations, homeowners and renters to repair or replace uninsured/underinsured disaster damaged property."

The loans are primarily for people who had their business, non-profit or home damaged by the March tornado in Jonesboro.

But according to the release, the administration also offers Economic Injury Disaster loans for businesses that didn't sustain physical damage but have difficulty conducting business because of the twister.

Northeast Arkansas residents in Craighead, Greene, Jackson, Lawrence, Mississippi and Poinsett and the Missouri county of Dunklin can apply.

The deadline to turn in applications for the loans is July 20 to receive loans for physical damage to properties. The deadline for businesses that have faced economic difficulties because of the tornado is Feb. 22, 2021.

Administration officials recommend that people first file to receive their insurance money to help with damages that occurred during the tornado.

Administrators have also set up a Virtual Disaster Loan Outreach Center. Representatives are available by phone at 916-735-1500 or by email at FOCWAssistance@sba.gov from 6 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. Monday through Friday, according to the release.

People can apply for the loans online at https://disasterloanassistance.sba.gov.

Day made the announcement at the Craighead County Quorum Court on Monday. The court met, with some justices of the peace continuing to utilize the opportunity to attend virtually, at 5:30 p.m. in the basement of the Courthouse Annex, as it has done since Gov. Asa Hutchinson approved for justices to begin meeting via Zoom. While most justices met in person, a few continue to meet online to protect themselves from the COVID-19 pandemic.
